items.title: City Housing Projects Call For Environmental Help
items.abstract: Housing project residents say the city encouraged them to “go green,” but did little to help them and in some circumstances, stood in their way.

items.title: Thursday Reading: Home Composting in the City
items.abstract: Home composting in the city, piecing together the fiscal deal’s effect on taxpayers, talking to other parents about guns and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: In Rural Minnesota, a 70-Acre Lab for Sustainable Living
items.abstract: Imagine a house that can go without heating for two days in a bitterly cold winter. Or a greenhouse with what may be the largest hot-air solar panel array in North America.

items.title: Graphic Design: What a Trip
items.abstract: For Caroline Baumann, of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, vintage type settings and luggage labels from her Swiss grandparents hold a special place in her heart.

items.title: In Israeli City of Haifa, a Liberal Arab Culture Blossoms
items.abstract: The embrace of secularism, feminism and gay rights in the cafes and bars of this cosmopolitan city is creating a counterpoint to Israeli Arabs’ traditional conservatism.

items.title: ‘Design Thinking’ for a Better You
items.abstract: A strategy called “design thinking” has helped numerous entrepreneurs and engineers develop successful new products and businesses. But can design thinking help you create healthful habits?

items.title: State Challenges Plan to Revive City Opera
items.abstract: In a filing in federal bankrupcty court, the New York State Attorney General’s office raises several questions about a proposed reorganization of the defunct opera company.

items.title: New York City
items.abstract: New books include Gerard Koeppel’s “City on a Grid: How New York Became New York.”
keywords: City on a Grid: How New York Became New York (Book)
Fun City: John Lindsay, Joe Namath, and How Sports Saved New York in the 1960s (Book)
The Con Men: Hustling in New York City (Book)

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: As His Parting Gift, Urban Meyer Gives Ohio State a Rose Bowl Victory
items.abstract: The coach, who served a suspension earlier this season, had already announced his retirement, but he coached his team to a win over Washington in his final game.

items.title: Mexico City as the Director of ‘Roma’ Remembers It (and Hears It)
items.abstract: Alfonso Cuarón revisits the sights and sounds of the neighborhood that inspired his critically acclaimed film.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: Judge Blocks New York City Law Aimed at Curbing Airbnb Rentals
items.abstract: The law was intended to prevent apartments from being used as illegal hotels. The decision could aid home-sharing services’ fights in other cities.

items.title: They Married at City Hall (But Didn’t Toss the Bouquet)
items.abstract: Three couples share their stories after marrying on a December day at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau, where the brides also rented their flowers.

items.title: Eric Adams Takes Office as New York City’s 110th Mayor at a Perilous Moment
items.abstract: Eric Adams, the city’s second Black mayor, faces difficult decisions over how to lead New York City through the next wave of the pandemic.

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: A New Mayor and a New Relationship Between City Hall and Albany
items.abstract: Unlike their feuding predecessors, Mayor Eric Adams and Gov. Kathy Hochul appear to be getting along. They have their reasons.

items.title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
items.abstract: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.

items.title: When Production Design Plays a Supporting Role
items.abstract: The visual environments of “West Side Story,” “The Humans” and “Nightmare Alley” feel as alive as the actors.
